isis.stitle: T 444E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (NAVPAK) (1997) - SECTION 2.2: HARD START/NO START DIAGNOSTICS - T 444E ENGINE - EST TOOL-FAULT CODES

svcprocinfo.para:
Refer to Table 2.7
for the EST tool - fault codes.

table.title: Table 2.7 EST Tool - Fault Codes FROM FORM EGED-195

entry.para: See electronic diagnostic form for codes

svcsubproc.title: Purpose
svcsubproc.para: To determine if the Electronic Control Module (ECM) has detected any fault conditions that would cause a hard or no start condition.

svcsubproc.title: Test Procedure

note.para: Turn all accessories and the ignition off, before connecting EST tool to ATA diagnostic connector.

svcsubproc.para:
Connect the Electronic Service Tool (EST) to the American Trucking Association (ATA) diagnostic connector. The connector is located on the lower left kick panel Figure 2.7
inside the cab. On school buses, it may be hidden by the body builders panel near the driver's left foot. The screen of the reader should light up as soon as the tool is plugged in.

note.para: The ATA connector supplies power to operate the EST. The EST will automatically power up as soon as it is plugged into the ATA connector.

figure.caption: Figure 2.7 Electronic Service Tool/ATA Connector Location

svcsubproc.para:
Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position, but do not start the engine. This will allow the EST to receive data from the electronic control components on the truck. Press "ENTER" for Navistar Engine Control Module menu screen ( Figure 2.8
). The information received will be data showing the current status of the engine.

figure.caption: Figure 2.8 Navistar Engine Control Module Menu Screen

svcsubproc.para:
From the main menu press the "↓" key to select " DIAGNOSTIC CODES". The selection will have the "↑ ↓" symbol on the screen which indicates there are other selections available. By pressing the "↓" key the other selections will display on the screen. Press "↓" key until "DIAGNOSTIC CODES" appears on the screen ( Figure 2.9
).
Next press "ENTER".You are now in the diagnostic codes selection of the tool. From this point, diagnostic codes can be accessed.

The first option that will appear is "ACTIVE CODES". By selecting this option, the fault codes which have been detected on the current (ignition) "key ON cycle" will be displayed ( Figure 2.10
).

Press "ENTER". If there are any "Active Codes", the first one will appear on the screen along with a description of the code. The number in the upper left hand corner represents the Flash Code number. This flash code number is referenced on the electronic diagnostic form. The numbers at the bottom of the screen represent the SAE codes. Press "↓" key to access additional codes. If there are not any codes "Active", "EMPTY" will appear on the screen.

Refer to Figure 2.11
for the complete Pro-link menu map.

figure.caption: Figure 2.11 Pro-link 9000 Operation In Diagnostic Tool Menu Map

svcsubproc.para:
To access "Inactive Codes" press the "FUNC" key. This will access the last prior menu selection. Then press the "↓" key to select "INACTIVE CODES". Press the "ENTER" key ( Figure 2.12
).

Inactive codes are faults that have occurred in the previous (ignition) 'key ON cycles" and are now stored in memory. An "Active Code" will become an "Inactive" code when the ignition (key) is shut off.
Record all fault codes and refer to Electronic Diagnostics form EGED-200 .

note.para: All current fault codes must be repaired and (cleared), before proceeding with further diagnostic testing.

svcsubproc.title: Possible Causes
svcsubproc.para: Electronic Control Module (ECM) detectable faults which will cause a no or hard start condition are:

item.para: Injection Pressure Regulator (IPR) output circuit check fault.
